direction.raw_text: You're doing it for what the money says. It says what it says to any player who gets big money: that they're worth it.

direction.raw_text: The offer says that. The money itself is redundant. (BEAT) I made one personal decision based on money in my life and I swore to never do that again.

direction.raw_text: So you're not going to Boston?

direction.raw_text: I haven't decided.

direction.raw_text: The Visalia Oaks and their 240 pound catcher, Jeremy Brown, who's scared of running to second. This was in a game six weeks ago.

direction.raw_text: hits the remote and the tape starts. The quality is poor and the camera is focused only on Jeremy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This guy's gonna start him off with a fastball low and in because he hasn't read the book on our guy and doesn't know that low and in is where he eats. Jeremy takes him to deep center -- We see JEREMY BROWN connect and the ball fly off the bat but the camera stays on JEREMY running to first. PAUL slows down the picture with the remote

direction.raw_text: and he knows that if he runs it's a stand-up double and he's running.

direction.raw_text: Go pal.

direction.raw_text: is what he's always been afraid of. It's all he can do to get himself back to first.

direction.raw_text: has been scrambling in the dirt to get safely back to first base.

direction.raw_text: Why's he laughing? I'm gonna fire that guy, why the hell is he -- PAUL Everybody's laughing. JEREMY's looking around the field now, looking at his own dugout. We can't see what he sees but he's confused.

direction.raw_text: And now Jeremy finds out why. Watch his face because this is art. He's just found out the ball went 60 feet over the fence. He'd hit a home run but he didn't know it. And JEREMY's face explodes into a smile. He slaps hands with the first base coach and begins his trot around the bases.

direction.raw_text: stares at this. He takes the remote and backs it up a little so he can see Jeremy's face again.
